(b) The owner of such property seeking to induce the county to accept same shall certify this conveyance to be his free act and deed and will dedicate same to the public use forever all such streets, alleys and easements, without restriction or reversion. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 1.3) Sec. 58-22. - Plat. Any property conveyed to the county under the provisions of this article shall be accompanied by a legible recordable plat depicting the finished streets and rights-of-way. The plat shall show, in case of a subdivision, the boundaries of the subdivision, the names of such streets or roadways, the names and record owners of any adjoining unplatted land in the case of a subdivision, the easements for public utilities, the location of existing roads or streets that adjoin or abut the streets or roadways proposed to be conveyed to the county, and those streets or roadways which extend to within 80 feet of the streets or roadways proposed to be conveyed to the county. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 1.4) Sec. 58-23. - Easements and installation of utilities. Streets and roadways sought to be conveyed to the county under the provisions of this article shall not contain within their right-of-way any easements for public utilities. Any installation of public utilities shall be paid in advance of the paving of such streets or roadways and, in circumstances wherein pavement breaks or utility connections or extensions are required, such break shall be repaved by such utility company at its sole expense and in compliance with the rules and regulations for paving. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 1.5) Sec. 58-24. - Paving required; expense of developer or subdivision. No streets or roadways shall be accepted by the county unless they are paved at the time of the proposed conveyance in such a manner as to meet the minimum standards as provided in this article. The entire cost of construction, grading, drainage, sloping, grassing, engineering, surveying, and all other expenses shall be borne by the developer or subdivider. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 1.6) Sec. 58-25. - Minimum right-of-way widths. The following minimum right-of-way widths shall apply:
(Res. of 8-1-1994, § 1.7) Sec. 58-26. - Basic construction. (a) Intersections. Streets intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible, and no intersection shall be at an angle less than 75 degrees. (b) Grading. All streets, roads and alleys shall be graded by the subdivider to provide the necessary paving, roadway, drainage, and safety requirements. (c) Storm drainage. An adequate drainage system including necessary curbs, pipes, culverts, headwalls and ditches as appropriate shall be provided for the property drainage of all surface water. Pipe size will be determined by the use of the rational method or the peak discharge method. (d) Installation of utilities. After grading is completed and before any base is applied, all of the underground utilities (water mains, sewer mains, gas mains, and all service connections related thereto) shall be installed completely throughout the length of the street and all driveways for houses to be built by the subdivider shall be cut and drained. (e) Slopes and shoulder improvements. The minimum ratio for all fill or cut slopes (including drainage ditches) shall be 2:1 and the minimum width of all shoulders from back edge of the curb, if installed, shall be eight feet. All shoulders shall slope one-half inch to the foot. When all construction is completed, all slopes shall be cleared of all rubbish and shall have a stand of grass to prevent undue erosion, either by sprigging or seeding. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 1.8) Sec. 58-27. - Roadway surfacing and paving. The minimum requirements to be adhered to for the surfacing and paving of streets proposed to be conveyed to the county are those established from time to time by the county building official or the minimum standards established by the state department of transportation for use in the state highway system. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 1.9) Sec. 58-28. - Minimum pavement width. All paved residential streets shall have a minimum pavement width of 27 feet from back of curb, or 22 feet from edge of pavement to edge of pavement if no curb or gutters are installed. The outside pavement for a cul-de-sac turnaround shall be a minimum diameter of 80 feet. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 1.10) Sec. 58-29. - Curbs and gutters. If curbs and gutters are installed, they shall be regular six- or four-inch rollover concrete curb and gutter, with a minimum overall width of 24 inches. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 1.11) Sec. 58-30. - Acceptance; deed. Streets and roadways when accepted by the county shall be on appropriate right-of-way deeds that convey fee simple title to such rights-of-way together with appropriate easements for ditches, slopes and drainage easements prepared by or at the expense of the developer or subdivider and approved by the county and without restriction or reservation. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 1.12) Sec. 58-31. - Driveways. For all driveways installed on any county road, the person seeking to construct the driveway is required to purchase the necessary drainage pipe that will be installed by the county. The size of the pipe necessary for the installation will be determined by the county road superintendent. (Res. of 8-1-1994, art. VII) Secs. 58-32—58-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SIGNS[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Uniform regulations as to public road signs, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-50 et seq.; outdoor advertising on the state highway system, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-70 et seq.
Sec. 58-51. - Applicability. (a) This article applies to all outdoor advertising signs abutting or visible from the Interstate 16 right-of-way in the county. (b) No sign shall be erected or maintained unless it is in compliance with the regulations of this article. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 2.1) Sec. 58-52. - Standards. (a) All signs must be constructed of durable materials and maintained in good condition. No sign may be permitted to become dilapidated. (b) All signs located on sites abutting or visible from the Interstate 16 right-of-way shall conform with O.C.G.A. § 32-6-50 et seq., and meet all federal and state requirements necessary to obtain a permit under state law. In the event the regulations of this article are more stringent than state or federal law, this article shall be controlling. (c) Any sign that advertises an activity, business, product, or service that has ceased existence, operation, or productivity shall be removed within six months of the discontinuance of the activity, business, product or service. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 2.1) Sec. 58-53. - Prohibited signs. (a) Signs imitating warning signals are prohibited. No sign shall display lights resembling the flashing lights customarily used in traffic signals or in police, fire, ambulance, or rescue vehicles; nor shall any signs use the words, slogans, dimensional shape and size, or colors of governmental traffic signs. (b) No signs, except traffic signs and signals and informational signs erected by a public agency, are permitted within any street or highway right-of-way. (c) Signs painted or attached to natural features (such as trees or rocks), telephone poles, utility poles, or fenceposts are prohibited. (d) Fluttering ribbons and banners are prohibited. (e) Signs using animation and running lights are prohibited. (f) Signs within 300 feet of any officially designated historical site or monument, except signs pertaining to that particular site or monument, are prohibited. (g) All outdoor advertising signs that are not within 100 feet of a regularly used part of the activity being advertised and located on the same property are prohibited. (h) All outdoor signs advertising property for sale or for lease that are not on the property being advertised for sale or lease are specifically prohibited. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 2.2) Sec. 58-54. - Permitted signs. (a) Home occupation signs. One nonilluminated professional or business nameplate not exceeding two square feet in area is permitted. (b) Signs regarding work under construction. One nonilluminated sign, not exceeding 40 square feet in area, displaying the name of the building, the contractors, the architects, the engineers, the owners, the financer, and the selling and development agencies is permitted upon the premises of any work under construction, alteration, or removal. Such sign shall be removed from the site within 30 days after the completion of the project. (c) Temporary subdivision signs. Temporary signs not exceeding 40 square feet in area announcing a land subdivision development are permitted on the premises of the land subdivision. Such signs shall be spaced not less than 300 feet apart. They shall be removed when 75 percent of the subdivision's lots are conveyed. (d) Private directional signs. Signs indicating the location and direction of premises available for or in process of development, but not erected upon such premises, and having inscribed thereon the name of the owner, developer, builder, or agent may be erected and maintained, provided that: (1) The size of any such sign may not exceed six square feet, and the length must not exceed four feet in length; and (2) Not more than one such sign may be erected on each 500 feet of right-of-way frontage. (e) Roof signs. Not more than one roof sign may be erected on the roof of any one building. No roof sign structure shall extend more than 25 feet above the elevation of the roof. (f) Wall signs. Signs on the walls of a building (including signs attached flat against the wall, painted wall signs, and projecting signs) shall meet the following requirements: (1) Signs on the front surface of a building. The total area of signs on the exterior front surface of a building shall not exceed 25 percent of the front surface of the building. (2) Signs on the side and rear surface of a building. The total area of signs on a side or rear surface of a building shall not exceed 50 percent of the exterior side or rear surface of the building respectively. (3) Projecting signs. Wall signs attached flat against a wall may not exceed more than 24 inches from the wall. (g) Illuminated signs. Illuminated devices shall be so placed and so shielded that light from the sign itself will not be directly cast into any residential district, sleeping rooms in any district, or the eyes of the driver of an automobile or other vehicle. (h) Nonconforming signs. Any legally erected sign which would become nonconforming as a result of this article is allowed to remain until purchased by the department of transportation or the county, provided that the sign owner meets all other requirements of county, state, and federal law. (Res. of 8-1-1994, § 2.3) Secs. 58-55—58-81. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - STRUCTURE NUMBERING
Sec. 58-82. - Street and road names; numbering. All streets, roads, or accesses to structures within the county, incorporated as well as unincorporated areas, whether maintained by the county or not, shall, at the sole discretion of the sole commissioner, be named and numbered as they are now, or in the future may be designated on the official map and index of the sole commissioner. Any street, road, or access not designated on the official index shall hereafter be referred to as designated on a said index for structure numbering purposes. (Ord. of 2-6-2007(2), § 2) Sec. 58-83. - Structure numbers assigned. (a) Structure numbers for dwelling units, places of business, industrial locations, and all other structures and uses requiring same shall be assigned by the 911 mapping department during and following the implementation stage of the system in each area of the county. (b) The 911 mapping department shall keep a record of all address numbers and road names assigned under this article. Such records may be maintained in data storage systems if so desired. (Ord. of 2-6-2007(2), § 3) Sec. 58-84. - Posting of designated structure numbers. (a) The owner or occupant or person in charge of any dwelling unit, structure or use to which has been assigned shall be notified in writing by the 911 mapping department of the number assigned to same at any time after the adoption date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. (b) Within 60 days after receipt of such written notification, the owner or occupant or person in charge of any dwelling unit, structure or use to which a number has been assigned shall cause the same to be posted and subsequently maintained in either one or two locations, depending on the conditions: (1) If the mailbox is located on the same side of the street and adjacent to the driveway or curb cut, the number may be affixed to the mailbox in letters four inches in height or larger and of a color specified by the 911 center. This subsection does not preclude an individual from also numbering the front entrance of the structure if so desired. (2) If the mailbox is not on the same side of the street and adjacent to the driveway or curb cut, the number shall be posted at two locations: a. The mailbox as prescribed by U.S. postal regulations; and b. On an aboveground sign attached to a post or other object at the driveway or curb cut. If attached to a post or other object at the driveway or curb cut, said post or object shall measure two to three feet in height. The numbers shall be five inches in height or higher and of a white reflective color contrasting with the color of the background, which shall be dark green. This subsection does not preclude an individual from also numbering the front entrance if so desired. (c) If a building is served by two or more driveways or curb cuts, the number shall be assigned and posted at the location determined to be most favorable by the 911 mapping department for emergency response purposes. (d) It shall be the duty of the owner, occupant, or person in charge of the dwelling unit, structure or use, upon affixing the new number, to remove any different number which might be mistaken for or be confused with the number assigned to the structure by the 911 mapping department. (e) If the assigned number cannot be posted as required by this section, the number shall be posted as prescribed by the 911 mapping department after consultation with the owner, occupant or person in charge of the dwelling unit, structure or use. (Ord. of 2-6-2007(2), § 4) Sec. 58-85. - Types of numbers. Two types of numbers are used in this article: (1) A primary address number to be assigned to each street or road frontage of each parcel of land, whether or not the parcel is occupied. The primary number is required to be posted only if the parcel is occupied by a dwelling unit, structure or use and the owner, occupant or person in charge is notified under section 58-84(a). Other primary numbers are reserved for future development of the numbered parcels and will be assigned at the time of the development. (2) Secondary numbers may be used when the number of units, structures, or uses coexists on the same parcel of land. Examples of parcels requiring secondary numbers include apartment projects, condominium projects, mobile home parks, office parks, planned unit developments and other uses where the use of secondary numbers is necessary to clarify the location of a unit or use for public safety purposes. To provide secondary numbers, the 911 mapping department shall work with the owner, manager, or person in charge of the project to determine a logical numbering system under the following guidelines: a. Existing numbered units and uses may retain the present set of addresses, with the approval of the 911 mapping department, with only the primary numbers complying with this article. b. Buildings on a single parcel with more than one and less than five units shall be given either letters (preferred) or number designations as requested by the owner. c. A single building on a single parcel of land and with five or more units shall be given numerical designations such as Suite 5, Apartment 5, etc., if so desired. d. Multiple structures on the same parcel of land may be given secondary number designations if the buildings are accessed from the main entrance to the project. Generally the number designations should increase in a clockwise direction from the main entrance. (Ord. of 2-6-2007(2), § 5) Sec. 58-86. - Implementation in stages. Because of the large and complex nature of the county and the existing numbering system now in place on some portions of the county, this article shall be implemented in stages covering small sections of the entire area without the need for the adoption of supplementary implementation resolutions for each section of the county. (Ord. of 2-6-2007(2), § 6) Sec. 58-87. - Exempt and excluded structures. The intent of this section is to exclude from this article those structures that do not present a significant danger to human life if destroyed by fire or other events. The following structures shall be excluded from the provisions: (1) Agricultural buildings not requiring a separate mailing address such as a barn, poultry house, outbuilding or equipment storage building as long as no phone service exists in said structure. Buildings used as a dwelling unit, office or the nominal workstation of an employee shall not be exempt. (2) Storage and accessory buildings for the use of the occupant of another building on the property. Building used as dwelling units, offices, or the nominal workstation of an employee, or requiring a separate mailing address, shall not be exempt. (Ord. of 2-6-2007(2), § 7) Sec. 58-88. - New structures and lots. (a) Structure numbers will be assigned to each new lot, tract or building site on the original drawings of a final subdivision plat, mobile home park plan, planned unit development or other plan requiring the approval of the planning department. (b) No building, electrical, plumbing, mechanical, or septic permit for any new or remodeled or repaired structure will be issued by the responsible county official following the implementation of this article in the affected area of the county until the owner, developer, or builder has procured from the 911 mapping department the official structure number or numbers and presents proof of the same to the responsible county official for issuance of said permit. Final approval for a certificate of occupancy of any principal building erected or repaired, or use requiring said number, shall be withheld until permanent and proper numbers have been displayed in accordance with the standards of this article. (Ord. of 2-6-2007(2), § 8) Sec. 58-89. - Utility company compliance. (a) Following the implementation of this article in any area of the county, all utility services regulated by the state public service commission or any utility cooperation service organization, shall withhold service from any building until the owner or requesting party has furnished the utility with a valid structure number. (b) It shall be the responsibility of the structure owner, or its occupant, to notify each affected utility service of implementation in each area by producing signed compliance forms of official numbers, provided by 911 mapping department, assigned to each affected structure or use. (c) All utility services are required to cooperate with the county 911 mapping department by providing a complete list of all customer information requested by the 911 mapping department to facilitate implementation of this article. This shall include all pertinent information such as, but not limited to, customer names, phone number, mailing address, physical address, utility meter number or other identifying number of information. Said information shall be provided in an electronic format compatible with software used by the 911 mapping department. (Ord. of 2-6-2007(2), § 9) Sec. 58-90. - Implementation for rendering nonemergency service. Every department and official under the jurisdiction of the sole commissioner shall not render any nonemergency service until the occupant, owner, or requesting individual has provided the department with a valid structure number on form provided by 911 mapping department. Nonemergency service includes any service with a valid structure number and any service provided by the sole commissioner except fire, rescue, law enforcement or emergency medical service. (Ord. of 2-6-2007(2), § 10)

div.head: Chapter 62 - SOLID WASTE
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 62-1—62-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - USER FEES
Sec. 62-19. - Purpose and intent. The county has constructed a convenience station for the receipt, transportation, and disposal of the solid waste of the county in an approved class D landfill. In connection therewith, the county establishes regulations and a reasonable user fee schedule for the use and operation of the county's solid waste convenience station and the transportation and disposal of solid waste therein. (Ord. of 12-29-1994, art. II(intro.)) State Law reference— Local solid waste regulation, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-30.9; local solid waste management plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1. Sec. 62-20. - Fee schedule. Users of the county solid waste convenience station shall pay resident or nonresident user fees in the amounts established from time to time by the sole commissioner. (Ord. of 12-29-1994, § 2.1(1—5)) State Law reference— Cost reimbursement fees and surcharges for local solid waste facilities, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-39; authority for enforcement of fees, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-39.3. Sec. 62-21. - Terms of payment. (a) Each person who brings solid waste to the convenience station will first place recyclable items in bins prior to having the disposable waste weighed. Users shall make payment to the county for waste disposal according to the fee schedule herein within 30 days after the end of the month in which the accumulative user fees for that user reaches the total sum of $25.00. For users whose accumulative fee does not exceed the total sum of $25.00 by the end of December of each year, such accumulated amount shall be paid on or before January 30 of the following year. (b) Any user account that has not been paid within 30 days after the same is due shall be turned over to the magistrate court for collection. (Ord. of 12-29-1994, §§ 2.2, 2.7) Secs. 62-22—62-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - RULES AND REGULATIONS
Sec. 62-46. - Recyclable items; asbestos shingles. (a) There will be no charge made for solid waste involving recyclable items (except the required certification that certain items such as refrigerators, freezers and air conditioners are free of Freon) that are placed in separate bins and which include the following: (1) Clear glass; (2) Dark glass; (3) Aluminum; (4) Scrap metal; (5) White goods, such as washing machines, stoves, hot water heaters, dryers and appliances; (6) Wood products, such as limbs, leaves and yard waste; (7) Newspaper. (b) No asbestos shingles shall be accepted; however, regular non-asbestos shingles will be accepted subject to payment of appropriate user fees. (Ord. of 12-29-1994, § 2.1(6, 7)) State Law reference— Asbestos Safety Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-12-1 et seq. Sec. 62-47. - Information to be provided by user. All users shall be required to provide at the weigh station basic information such as name, telephone number, address, vehicle tag number, and a summary statement of types of solid waste being disposed of. (Ord. of 12-29-1994, § 2.3) Sec. 62-48. - Smoking prohibited. No smoking shall be allowed at weigh station or at any point on the waste disposal site. (Ord. of 12-29-1994, § 2.4) Sec. 62-49. - Littering prohibited. Each user hauling solid waste to the convenience station shall do so in such a manner as to prevent any litter, trash, debris, or any solid waste of any nature from blowing off or falling off the vehicle in which such solid waste is being transported. (Ord. of 12-29-1994, § 2.5) Sec. 62-50. - Ashes and hot residue prohibited. No solid waste of any nature shall be brought to the convenience station that contains hot ashes or other hot residue. (Ord. of 12-29-1994, § 2.9) Sec. 62-51. - Penalties. Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-7. (Ord. of 12-29-1994, § 2.8) Sec. 62-52. - Restraining system required. Any person hauling gravel, soil, garbage, trash, waste, papers, junk, rubbish, debris, or other materials which are likely to blow or fall off any vehicle, truck or trailer hauling such materials shall be required to have the same covered by a tarpaulin, canvas, or other restraining system. It shall unlawful for any person to operate a vehicle, truck, or trailer in violation of this section and it shall also be unlawful for any owner of such vehicle, truck or trailer to knowingly permit the operation of such vehicle, truck or trailer. Violation of this section may be punishable by a fine up to $1,000.00 and/or 60 days in jail and/or public works. Any violation of this section may be heard in the magistrate court, the probate court, or the superior court of Bleckley County, Georgia. (Ord. No. 2017-ORD-001, 5-18-2017) Secs. 62-53—62-75. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT AUTHORITY
Sec. 62-76. - Establishment; purpose and intent. The county, after diligent study and review, hereby joins with the other participants in finding and declaring that there is a need for an authority to function in the area of solid waste management. In conjunction with the other participants, the county hereby activates the Heart of Georgia Regional Solid Waste Management Authority (the "authority"), a public corporation created as an institution of purely public charity, to perform an essential governmental function on the exercise of the power conferred upon it by this article. (Ord. of 7-16-1992, § 1) State Law reference— Local development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq. Sec. 62-77. - Board of directors. (a) The board of directors of the authority shall meet and shall appoint and declare by resolution of the authority an additional member of the board of directors. The members of the board of directors of the authority shall elect one of their members as chairman and another as vice-chairman and shall also elect a secretary and a treasurer or a secretary-treasurer, either of whom may be, but need not be, a member of the board of directors. (b) The directors shall receive no compensation for their services but shall be reimbursed for their actual expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. (c) The directors may make bylaws and regulations for the governing of the authority and the operation of any projects of the authority and may delegate to one or more of the officers, agents and employees of the authority such powers and duties as may be deemed necessary and proper. The authority shall adopt bylaws providing in detail for its operation, meetings, and other functions, and the authority may provide in such bylaws for the establishment of an executive committee to operate in certain functions of the authority to be specified in such bylaws. The bylaws shall be adopted by the vote of a two-thirds majority of the members of the board of directors of the authority. (Ord. of 7-16-1992, § 2) State Law reference— Boards of directors of local development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-5. Sec. 62-78. - Powers. The authority shall have all of the powers granted by law to regional solid waste management authorities, including, but not limited to, the power to research, study, and plan for the solid waste management needs of the participants and to gather data and research all phases of the solid waste management needs of the participants; provided, however, that the authority shall not have the power to borrow money, issue bonds or enter into any financial obligations without the authorization of each of the participants who will participate in the repayment of such obligation. (Ord. of 7-16-1992, § 3) State Law reference— Powers of authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-6.

div.head: Chapter 66 - TAXATION
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 66-1—66-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LOCAL SALES AND USE TAX
Sec. 66-19. - Levy. With the approval of the voters of Bleckley County at an election duly held on January 9, 1978, there is hereby levied and imposed a sales and use tax at the rate of one percent pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-8-110.1. The tax imposed shall correspond, so far as practical, except as to rate, with O.C.G.A. §§ 48-8-1 through 48-8-67, the Georgia Retailers and Consumers Sales and Use Tax Act and no item or transaction which is not subject to taxation under the provisions of said state law chapter shall be subject to the said one percent tax levied hereby. (Res. of 1-10-1978) Sec. 66-20. - Administration. The tax hereby levied shall be exclusively administered and collected by the state revenue commissioner for the use and benefit of the county and the City of Cochran as provided by said laws. (Res. of 1-10-1978) Secs. 66-21—66-43. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - JOINT SALES AND USE TAX
Sec. 66-44. - Levy of joint tax. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-8-82, there is levied and imposed by the county a combination city-county local sales and use tax within the special district whose boundaries are coterminous with the boundaries of the county. (Res. of 3-28-1979) Sec. 66-45. - Distribution of proceeds. The proceeds of the combination sales and use tax shall be distributed as follows: The City of Cochran shall receive 42 percent and the county shall receive 58 percent. (Res. of 3-28-1979) State Law reference— Distribution of proceeds of joint local sales and use tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-89. Secs. 66-46—66-63. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - AD VALOREM TAX
Sec. 66-64. - Purpose and intent. (a) The sole commissioner has determined that the nonpayment of ad valorem taxes by property owners effectively shifts a greater tax burden to property owners willing and able to pay their share of such taxes. (b) The failure to pay ad valorem taxes creates significant barriers to marketability of property and nonjudicial tax foreclosure procedures are inefficient and lengthy, commonly resulting in title to real property that is neither marketable nor insurable. (c) Tax delinquency in many instances also results in properties that present health and safety hazards to the public. (d) The sole commissioner finds that the alternative to nonjudicial tax foreclosure procedures authorized by the O.C.G.A. §§ 48-4-75 through 48-4-81 is an effective means of eliminating health and safety hazards by putting certain tax delinquent properties back in the tax rolls and into productive use. (Ord. of 8-20-1998) Sec. 66-65. - Procedure. In addition to any other rights and remedies provided under state law for the enforcement of tax liens by the county, the collecting officers for taxes may proceed with judicial in rem of tax foreclosures for delinquent taxes in accordance with the provisions of the O.C.G.A. §§ 48-4-75 through 48-4-81, and this article shall be sufficient authority for use of the provisions of the judicial tax foreclosure procedures as set out in said state law sections by the appropriate tax collecting officials of the county. (Ord. of 8-20-1998) Sec. 66-66. - In rem judicial foreclosures. (a) The alternate method of judicial in rem foreclosure procedures as set out in O.C.G.A. 48-4-76—48-4-81 is hereby authorized to be used by the tax commissioner of the county and other tax collecting municipalities of properties located in the county. (b) The criteria for the selection of properties to be subject to the provision of judicial in rem tax foreclosures include the following: (1) When it appears that the taxes will not be paid before sale or the property will not be redeemed before the end of the redemption period. (2) When the taxes are owed on an estate or the property has title problems. (3) When dealing with a tract of land that could be deemed as an excessive levy. (4) When the property is suitable to be acquired by a land bank authority. (5) When there are environmental problems associated with the property. (Ord. of 3-17-2011) Secs. 66-67—66-88. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - GROSS PREMIUMS TAX ON INSURANCE
Sec. 66-89. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Gross direct premiums means gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). (Res. of 8-18-1983, § 1; Res. of 8-18-1984, § 6.1) Sec. 66-90. - Levy; rate; applicability; life insurance excepted. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2, there is hereby levied for the year 1984 and for each year thereafter an annual tax upon each insurer doing business within the unincorporated area of the county, in an amount equal to 2.5 percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year on all insurance, other than life insurance, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(2)—(5). (Res. of 8-18-1983, § 1; Res. of 8-18-1984, § 6.1) Secs. 66-91—66-108. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - TAX ON DEPOSITORY FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS
Sec. 66-109. - Levy; definitions. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Depository financial institutions means state and national banks, state building and loan associations and federal savings and loan associations. Gross receipts means gross receipts as defined in O.C.G.A. § 78-6-93. (b) In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is hereby levied for the year 1984 and for each year thereafter an annual business license tax upon all depository financial institutions located within the county at a rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of said depository financial institutions. (Res. of 10-24-1983, § 1) Sec. 66-110. - Minimum business license tax. The minimum annual amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to this article shall be $1,000.00. (Res. of 10-24-1983, § 2) Sec. 66-111. - Filing of return; form. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(c), each depository financial institution subject to the tax set forth in this article shall file a return of its gross receipts with the sole commissioner on March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts are measured. The return shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of revenue based on the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The sole commissioner shall assess and collect the tax levied pursuant to this article based upon the information provided in the return. (Res. of 10-24-1983, § 3) Sec. 66-112. - Payment due date. Taxes levied pursuant to this article shall be due no later than 30 days after filing of the return described in section 66-111 unless extended by the sole commissioner. (Res. of 10-24-1983, § 4)

div.head: Chapter 70 - WATER AND SEWAGE SERVICES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 70-1—70-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WATER SERVICE
Secs. 70-19—70-39. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ON-SITE SEWAGE MANAGEMENT
Sec. 70-40. - Short title. This article shall be known, referred to, and may be cited as the "On-Site Sewage Management Law of Bleckley County." (Ord. of 10-21-1999(2), § 1) State Law reference— Standards for on-site sewage management systems, O.C.G.A. § 31-2-7; regulation of on-site sewage management systems, O.C.G.A. §§ 31-3-5, 31-3-5.1. Sec. 70-41. - Purpose and intent. It is the intent and policy of the sole commissioner to: (1) Promote the health, safety, convenience, order, prosperity, and general welfare of the county and its residents; (2) Protect the natural resources, the environment, and the public health of the county; (3) Facilitate the adequate provision of on-site sewage management for all development in the local jurisdiction; (4) Protect significant groundwater recharge areas from pollution by spills, discharges, leaks, impoundments, applications of chemicals, injections, and other development; (5) Promote the wise use of wetlands and protect them from alterations that will significantly affect or reduce their primary functions for water quality, floodplain and erosion control, groundwater recharge, aesthetic natural areas, and wildlife habitat areas; (6) Establish measures to preserve an adequate supply of safe drinking water and a quality for state waters which is necessary to protect the health and welfare of the public as well as to provide for future growth; (7) Protect the environment, including the soils, air quality, and water resources, from pollution and inappropriate development; to assist in the orderly, efficient, and integrated development of the county; and (8) Require permits for new development or location within the county. (Ord. of 10-21-1999(2), § 2) Sec. 70-42. - Responsibility for administration. The sole commissioner, because of the need for coordination, charges the county health department with the responsibility for administering this article and ensuring compliance with its provisions. (Ord. of 10-21-1999(2), § 5) Sec. 70-43. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Hazardous waste means any solid waste that has been defined as a hazardous waste in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) pursuant to the federal act codified as 40 CFR 261, and as amended. Lot means the contiguous land in the same ownership which is not divided by any public highway or alley, including any part thereof subject to any easement for any purpose other than a public highway or alley, but excluding any part thereof severed from another lot where the severance creates any nonconformity of size or use. Perennial river or stream means a river/stream or section of a river or stream that normally flows continuously throughout the whole year. Protected river corridor means all land, inclusive of islands, in areas of a protected river within a distance of 100 feet horizontally on both sides of the river measured from the uppermost part of the riverbank; the area between the top of the bank and the edge of the water is included in the protected area. Riverbank or streambank means the rising ground, bordering a river or a stream, which serves to confine the water to the natural channel during the normal course of flow. Section 404 refers to section 404 (33 USC 1344) of the U.S. Clean Water Act, 33 USC 1251 et seq. Septic tank means a subsurface impervious tank designated to temporarily retain sewage or similar waterborne wastes, together with: (1) A sewer line constructed with solid pipe, with the joints sealed, connecting such impervious tank with a plumbing stubout; and (2) A subsurface system of trenches, piping, and other materials constructed to drain the clarified discharge from the tank and distribute it underground to be absorbed or filtered. Subdivision means all divisions of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, building sites, or other divisions for the purpose of sale, legacy, or building development, whether immediate or future. This shall include all divisions or resubdivisions of land involving a new road or change in existing roads. Excluded from this definition is the combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased. Utility means public or private water or sewer piping systems, water or sewer pumping stations, electric power lines, fuel pipelines, telephone lines, roads, driveways, bridges, river/lake access facilities, stormwater systems and railroads or other utilities identified by a local government. Wetlands means those areas that are inundated or saturated by surface water or groundwater at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances do support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions. Wetlands generally include swamps, marshes, bogs, and similar areas. The ecological parameters for designating wetlands include hydric soils, hydrological vegetation, and hydrological conditions that involve a temporary or permanent source of water to cause soil saturation. (Ord. of 10-21-1999(2), § 3) Sec. 70-44. - Violations and penalties. (a) Violators. Violation of these provisions, prohibitions, and installation restrictions by any private individual, landowner, builder, remodeler, contractor, licensed electrician, licensed plumber, septic tank dealer or installer, mobile or manufactured home dealer or mover, or developer, or installation and delivery of any utility services by a public or private utility to any property which holds a septic tank system installed against these prohibitions and restrictions, shall be a violation of this article. (b) Penalty. Any person violating, neglecting, or refusing to comply with any provision of this article shall be subject to penalties as set forth in section 1-7. (Res. of 6-20-1986(2), § 7; Ord. of 10-21-1999(2), § 10) Sec. 70-45. - Permit. (a) Septic tanks permitted. No septic tank shall be installed where a public sewer is accessible to the premises involved, nor in any place where the health inspector deems the use of a septic tank to be a menace to human health or a nuisance to the general welfare of the county. (b) On-site sewage management permit required. Prior to the construction of any house or building, or alteration or addition thereto, and prior to the location or relocation of any mobile home in the county from which sewage must be disposed of by means of a septic tank or alternative system, an on-site sewage management permit must be obtained from the county health department, in addition to any other required building or relocation permits. (c) Subdivisions. Where private systems for the disposal of sewage and other liquid wastes are proposed in any planned subdivision, before any person may develop the subdivision and before the sale of any lots therein or the erection of any buildings thereon, the owner or his designee shall file such plats, plans, and specifications as the health inspector may deem necessary to evaluate the permissibility of the planned subdivision sewage systems. Upon approval, the health inspector shall issue a permit as set forth in this article. (d) Permit coordination. The permit shall not be issued, and no construction, erection, move, or other activity regulated by this article may proceed, until the county health department issues an on-site sewage management construction permit or a site approval letter, whichever is appropriate, so that all lots proposed to be used or subdivided would satisfy the requirements of this article, including the rules of the state department of human resources for on-site sewage management systems. (e) Form and contents of application. The application for the permit shall be made on the form prescribed by the health department and shall include, at a minimum, the following information: (1) The name and address of the applicant; (2) The address of the location of the building or mobile home for which the permit is sought; (3) For residential structures, the number of bedrooms contained or to be contained therein; and (4) For commercial or industrial structures, the amount of the anticipated water usage. (f) Duties of health department. It is the duty of the county health department to evaluate the proposed structure and to issue the on-site sewage management permit for those sites that comply with the rules and regulations promulgated by the county health department for on-site sewage management systems. (g) Duties of applicant. It shall be the duty of the property owner or building contractor, or the applicant, if different from the property owner or building contractor, to request evaluation by the health department, prior to beginning construction or prior to locating or relocating a mobile home, for purposes of determining if the septic tank system complies with the rules and regulations promulgated by the county health department for on-site sewage management systems. (h) Minimum lot size. All lots intended for residential or other use within the county shall be of such size as is specified by the county health department according to the Rules of Georgia Department of Human Resources Public Health for On-Site Sewage Management Systems Manual for On-Site Sewage Management and/or this article, whichever is more stringent; provided, however, that if the lot includes or will include a septic tank, it shall be: (1) Not less than 1.5 acres if a water well is used on the same lot; or (2) Not less than 0.75 acre if there will be no water well and the lot will use the public water supply system. (i) Requirements are minimum. The regulations and requirements set by this article shall be the minimum requirements. (j) Preexisting uses. The provisions of this article regarding minimum lot size shall not apply to lots that are the subject of a plat recorded prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived or a deed conveying ownership to the current owner recorded prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived. (k) Compliance with state and federal regulations. All developments, structures, and uses within the county shall also meet the requirements of all other local, federal and state regulations in effect, including but not limited to department of transportation regulations, state fire marshal regulations, the state's uniform construction codes, state department of natural resources, and state environmental protection division environmental rules and regulations. Issuance of a permit under this article does not constitute certification of compliance with such codes or regulations, and does not abrogate responsibility of the owner to so comply. (l) Map interpretation. If there is any uncertainty as to whether a lot, portion of lot, or a proposed construction or location impacts an environmental resource regulated by this article because of interpretation of the applicable map, the decision of the sole commissioner or the county health department shall take precedence and be considered correct and final, but may be appealed as set forth in this article. (m) Appeal. Any person who feels aggrieved by a decision of the sole commissioner or the county health department, as appropriate, regarding map interpretation may at his own expense request reconsideration. Such reconsideration shall include submission of scientific evidence for reversal of the alleged error in map interpretation, and such evidence must be documented by a state registered engineer, geologist, or soils scientist. To obtain a reversal of the decision of map interpretation, the evidence must be acceptable to the state department of natural resources' environmental protection division, and the sole commissioner, and/or the county health department. Any costs for submission of evidence to the state department of natural resources' environmental protection division shall be borne by the person requesting reconsideration. (n) Coordination with zoning and other regulation. The provisions of this article shall be coordinated with any zoning or other regulations adopted by the sole commissioner, and if there is any conflict with those zoning or other regulations, the stricter provisions shall apply. If zoning is or has been adopted, the provisions of this article shall be considered an overlay, or additional requirements to the requirements of underlying zoning regulations and district. (o) Fees. Any fees for applications, inspections, and the issuance of permits or certificates required or issued under the provisions of this article shall be paid by the person seeking such permit at the time of application in advance of the issuance of such permits or certificates. The amount of such fees, if any, shall be those established by the sole commissioner from time to time. (Res. of 6-20-1986(2), §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 10-21-1999(2), §§ 4.1—4.10) Sec. 70-46. - Variances. When due to a particular hardship or extraordinary circumstance of the property involved which is not easily corrected, it is impractical for an owner or developer to comply with all of the requirements of this article, the sole commissioner shall be authorized to vary such requirements (under its jurisdiction) only to such extent as to provide fairness to the owner or developer and as to not violate the intent and purposes of this article. Such variances shall only be granted in an official public meeting, and the reasons for granting them shall be entered into the minutes of the public meeting. (Ord. of 10-21-1999(2), § 9) Sec. 70-47. - Jurisdiction. The sole commissioner or the county board of health, as appropriate, may bring complaints of violation of any provision of this article before the magistrate court of the county.
